awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: HybriD3: Discovery, Design, Dissemination of Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Semiconductor Materials for Optoelectronic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project, called "HybriD3", aims to accelerate the Design, Discovery, and Dissemination of new crystalline organic-inorganic hybrid semiconductors. The materials to be considered generally consist of a suitable inorganic semiconductor that forms a connected framework, into which targeted organic components integrate. While organic materials have unique attributes, including light weight, mechanical flexibility and possible strong light emission, inorganic systems offer their own unique strengths related to excellent semiconducting and optical characteristics. Notably, while traditional semiconductors (e.g., silicon) are strictly inorganic, organic-inorganic hybrids open up the full arsenal of synthetic organic chemistry for tuning and refining the resulting materials and associated properties. Specifically, the current project targets the paradigm of so-called organic-inorganic (or hybrid) perovskites, aiming to identify new materials opportunities for light-emitting diodes, with better suitability for addressing the important target of energy-efficient lighting and cost-effective manufacturing techniques. However, the materials space to be explored is general, versatile, not yet nearly exhaustively charted, and will likely expose materials with very different, unprecedented and tunable functionality, as the research focuses on understanding previously unexplored interactions between the organic and inorganic hybrid components. A key deliverable for dissemination will be a comprehensive, easily-browsable database of existing, predicted and newly synthesized organic-inorganic hybrids to ensure accelerated development of this materials space among the wider community of researchers now converging around this materials class.

Technical Description: HybriD3 is an integrated, multi-pronged effort, leveraging theory and computation, synthesis, spectroscopy and optoelectronic device prototyping. The activity will create and leverage techniques for more effective computational predictions of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, their carrier properties and excitations, for targeted synthesis and characterization of identified materials prospects. The project will also target proof-of-concept device (primarily light emission) demonstration for the developed hybrid materials. It will thus enable better understanding of key physical processes such as carrier transport, charge/energy transfer between the organic and inorganic sub-components, carrier recombination, and how these properties can be manipulated by refining structure, synthesis and/or deposition of the thin-films or bulk crystals. The planned database will play a long-term role as a go-to resource for an entire community. The PIs will also promote the HybriD3 data for inclusion in broader community databases such as the Materials Project, aflowlib, or the NoMaD Data Repository. Finally, sustainable data dissemination will be ensured by a collaboration with industry leader Springer Materials, to include the HybriD3 data in their product. The PIs also plan to release the HybriD3-developed software and database as open source and build a user community around the project by ensuring that interested researchers are able to contribute to the HybriD3-developed codebase. This will allow a wider growth of the project. This aspect is of special interest to the software cluster in the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure, which has provided co-funding for this award.

por.por_cntn:
This project, called "HybriD3", aimed to accelerate the Design, Discovery, and Dissemination (D3) of new crystalline hybrid organic-inorganic semiconductors (HOIS), particularly those derived from a structural paradigm known as perovskites. HOIS incorporate both organic and inorganic functionality in an atomically ordered fashion, with different dimensionality of the components in space. As an example, the accompanying Figure shows a hybrid perovskite semiconductor that was computationally predicted in this project, based on the organic semiconductor tetracene as the molecular component and on lead iodide as the inorganic component.

Intellectual Merit: Between the project's inception in 2017 and the project end in 2023, the field has evolved extremely rapidly and so has the project, with several key insights originating from the program. Originally a collaboration between six principal investigators and their groups at three different universities, the project broke new ground both related to synthesis as well as simulation of novel HOIS materials based on the layered paradigm shown in the accompanying Figure. Computationally predicted organic/inorganic energy level alignments were shown to agree with optical properties inferred experimentally, a critical capability for rational design of future hybrid semiconductors and a cornerstone for follow-up studies both inside and outside the project. Experimentally and computationally, the "quantum well" nature of the materials and their practical tunability in four different quantum well types were fully unraveled throughout the project. The project contributed several novel perovskites in which the molecular arrangement breaks spatial symmetry, introducing spin effects into the structure that may be promising for future new device categories based on spin properties of electrons and light. This work has stimulated follow-up studies by other projects and researchers in the broader community. A further key accomplishment relates to the interaction of several HOIS materials with strong laser fields, creating excitations that interact strongly with lattice vibrations. In the collaborative partner project at North Carolina State University, experimental work in this direction led to the discovery of a quantum phenomenon called superfluorescence at room temperature in HOIS materials. The underlying, macroscopically coherent quantum state of the material may lend itself to the design of future quantum information devices, with a tentative explanation of the stable quantum state supported by computational simulations carried out in the Duke University component of the project. In short, the project has, in numerous ways, contributed to discovery and understanding of atomic-scale processes in HOIS that can be accessed experimentally, demonstrating the prospects of this group of semiconductors for potential future applications well beyond the recent focus of the field, i.e., photovoltaic applications.

Broader Impacts: A key component of the project was the creation of a curated database of properties related to crystalline HOIS, a field that has been immensely active in terms of new materials discoveries but for which no organized data curation and collection effort exists. Over the lifetime of the project, a database, called HybriD3, was established that collects material properties for over 500 distinct materials, including atomic structure, light emission and absorption properties, phase transitions and many others - in principle, any property that can be reproducibly associated with a material can be mapped into the database. This database is already becoming an important resource for the community and has also been incorporated into the industry-leading SpringerMaterials database, an unfunded project collaborator, in addition to the original database version. Beyond the potential role of the curated data in other academic research and in industry, the project, including the data curation part, has contributed significantly to education and training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels, with numerous project participants entering the academic or industrial workforce related to materials science. Importantly, well over 10 undergraduate students (located in North Carolina as well as several other universities across the U.S.) contributed to the research, with some playing key roles in the project, introducing them to advanced concepts in the materials science of semiconductors. Several of these students are now pursuing graduate studies at top universities, including Stanford and MIT. Finally, the conceptual insights gained during the project are amenable to incorporation into physics, chemistry or materials science oriented classes, offering an accessible and fascinating introduction to complex, high-definition semiconductor materials that can be designed based on intuitive principles grounded in basic organic and inorganic chemistry.
